document.title: History and Social Science Standards of Learning for Virginia Public Schools

435B498A96EB48B3B3F740301F755AE1.description:
examining the impact of the ideas, innovations, and advancements of Virginians on a global
market.

AAB0AA8D09394E8F8A91A8FC3DDE48DB.description: examining major products and industries important to Virginia; and

3EF362C3A7974C05A7E17E9941EE52FB.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to explain Virginia’s role in the global
economy in the 21st Century by

913E98DA6CA24A6C922EB8610E3DB065.description:
The student will use history and social science skills to recognize why Virginia is known as the
“Mother of Presidents”.

D9C7E6F53A6A402599ADF52892BFAA13.description:
investigating the political, social, and economic effects of choices made during the Civil
Rights Era by Virginians including, but not limited to Maggie Walker, Robert Russa
Moton, Barbara Johns, Samuel Wilbert Tucker, Oliver W. Hill, Sr., Irene Morgan, Arthur
R. Ashe, A. Linwood Holton, Jr., and L. Douglas Wilder.

7BE7A89EF0C8490F99C934763C21F387.description:
explaining the social and political events connected to disenfranchisement of African
American voters in Virginia in the early 20th century, desegregation, court decisions, and
Massive Resistance, with emphasis on the role of Virginians in the Supreme Court cases,
including, but not limited to Brown v. Board of Education; and

19F49C45C0AC42208E1D571E0E0CA792.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to understand the Civil Rights
Movement in Virginia by

606BE3B1CB84434299B902BF5F43E9F0.description: describing the contributions made by military veterans and Medal of Honor recipients.

281936D205694BFF96724EE482307671.description: examining how key leaders and citizens prepared for wartime; and

6754F06A8FFB4935AED38CEEE34760CB.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to understand the role Virginians played
in American history during World War I and World War II by

31CB16A521B74ACAB1C532CB4A7C47FB.description: explaining the economic and social transition from a rural society to a more urban society.

0848FFF7C9BA4D42A50887846D092106.description:
explaining the importance of railroads, waterways, new industries, and the growth of cities
to Virginia’s economic development in the late 1800s; and

BDE5229597B04EB8837F686F1E4A4FEB.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to understand the ways in which
Virginia became interconnected and diverse by

0B01FA2700B943C9BE82BF7F1A13E535.description: analyzing the effects of segregation and “Jim Crow” laws on life in Virginia.

40EAB0AD73B24A259AF0538E4F3485D6.description: describing the effect of the Supreme Court’s decision in Plessy v. Ferguson; and

62DD6AFCAB5B4377B21825187EAC6E34.description: discussing the election of African American leader John Mercer to Congress in 1890;

EE3F31CD4CE84C1886057FF402D80EA7.description:
describing the role that the “Freedmen’s Schools” played in the lives of African Americans
in Virginia after the Civil War;

63958E082D994A36850F336E16D27A22.description: examining the effects of Reconstruction on life in Virginia;

966E7D5EA7A944D5BACB7174F5EE87AF.description:
describing what the Thirteenth, Fourteenth, and Fifteenth Amendments to the Constitution
accomplished;

233B8EA7A2704AD79AB1CFC2468E0627.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to explain the reconstruction of Virginia
following the Civil War by

01A79B88BFFE47FF90906BF120E60423.description:
evaluating the experiences and contributions of Indigenous Peoples and enslaved and free
Blacks and their allies during the war, including, but not limited to Elizabeth Van Lew and
Mary Bowser.

834C27BD205340DFB179C239E2E9A1D8.description:
identifying and explaining the leadership roles of Virginians, including, but not limited to
Thomas “Stonewall” Jackson, Robert E. Lee, William Harvey Carney, Winfield Scott, and
Powhatan Beaty; and

EEDDE4467F6A4497AD3B3667243E7CA1.description: identifying major battles that took place in Virginia;

35C8E8BD8A2146BDBE7490AF94A33BE4.description:
explaining major events and issues that divided Virginians and led to secession, war, and
the creation of West Virginia;

FEB9DA210D6F430B837818F923D17A01.description:
explaining the significance of the Underground Railroad and the contributions of Harriet
Tubman;

E0F30C17F856443E842195021F609242.description:
describing how the institution of slavery was the cause of the Civil War, and secondary
factors that contributed to the secession of the southern states;

C094ED51BE6B4278A18FE432CE27A419.description: explaining the role of John Brown and the impact of the raid at Harper’s Ferry;

F3895A84B0D44E1B85300CC68E89B4B6.description:
The students will apply history and social science skills to understand the key people, events,
and issues of the Civil War and Virginia’s role by

AD4E0FF709BF48808B03E25396B8074B.description:
explaining the causes and events of Nat Turner’s Rebellion and how it impacted the
institution of slavery.

5390F70625BA41F4BD091CFCD875D9CE.description:
explaining how geographical features and technological advances impacted the western
movement in the first half of the 1800s; and

ADF820AE59474EDC828A5B48B1FA27EB.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to explain the establishment and growth
of the new American nation with emphasis on the role of Virginians and events in Virginia
during the 18th and 19th centuries by

3E4C008EDEE849C496D22D56E0730D3F.description: Political Growth and Western Expansion: 1775 to the Mid-1800s

FC69B27C05754722807DC7CBEF184D4A.description: identifying the importance of the American victory at Yorktown.

A9D3B98D4DDF442C8D7C27D5E9D17E14.description:
identifying the reasons for the relocation of Virginia’s capital from Williamsburg to
Richmond; and

5A27EF820FE5492BB900A8794B1A252E.description:
examining the important contributions, leadership, and experiences of Virginians during the
war, including, but not limited to George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, George Mason,
James Madison, James Armistead Lafayette, Indigenous Peoples, women, and free and
enslaved Blacks;

21F6629C98F742148A1043E589A32B1E.description:
explaining the principles and events that convinced the colonists to declare independence
and go to war with Great Britain, as expressed in the Declaration of Independence;

74D23880AEA64D21BAF3567CD3ED6FB8.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to explain Virginia and Virginians’ role
during the American Revolution by

716F5F87914D48EF94027FA8A0EC0111.description: describing ways people exchanged goods and services in Colonial Virginia.

A106BEC89437430B9B6E548A9F90F250.description:
explaining the reasons for the relocation of Virginia’s capital from Jamestown to
Williamsburg; and

1298EC048C69451EB623100F9521D004.description: describing the laws that established race-based enslavement;

56953CF269EC4D409175841E9848F127.description:
examining how colonial Virginia reflected the culture of Indigenous Peoples, European
(English, Scots-Irish, German) immigrants, and Africans;

34DB9A8D3FD944EE920E235144F85150.description: explaining the importance and influence of agriculture;

56F67CBE5231419BA77D340F4AB4830C.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to understand life in the Virginia colony
by

BFBD8298D82F4B538A4BEE27279D4514.description:
identifying the significance of establishing the General Assembly (1619), the first
representative legislative body in English America.

0CC05B46C043453B96E79677F169E4F1.description:
analyzing the impact of the arrival of Africans and women to the Jamestown settlement;
and

AEB747616BC241228AA9EEFF611A26C1.description:
describing the interactions between the English colonists and the Indigenous Peoples,
including the role of the Powhatan in the survival of the colonists;

2C7F3D697F7F4746AB49C112E66433AF.description:
describing the importance of the Virginia Company of London Charter (April 10, 1606) in
establishing the Jamestown colony;

0521CEFEBEA5400CB82776640C266E2D.description: describing the economic and geographic influences on the decision to settle at Jamestown;

B3DB03576ED442B98C3D37EB09BB338E.description: explaining the reasons for English colonization;

AD3DB221C7AB42A083F48161DADDAF5F.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to explain the causes and effects of
events associated with the first permanent English settlement in North America by

C4CD5A00A2D44173A6D0949E9C2D3212.description:
describing the lives and cultures of Virginia’s Indigenous Peoples leading to the present
day.

3BF06D73337844379B9862F94541AE3C.description:
describing the relationships and interactions of Virginia’s Indigenous Peoples and their
environment, circa 1600; and

A9BFDC9BC3E646F2B08782A329AFF68C.description: describing the diversity among the Indigenous nations;

A68450BA371D49DCBE2CAE80F2842CC8.description:
describing Virginia’s three most prominent Indigenous language groups (i.e., the
Algonquian, the Siouan, and the Iroquoian);

8A767B7334194B999818A806421B80AE.description:
describing how archaeologists have recovered artifacts from important places in the history
of Indigenous people, including, but not limited to Werowocomoco;

5309E6F7A4B14DE9800676D7D65D1DBD.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to describe the Indigenous nations of
Virginia past and present by

D049F39B15CD454ABB2920D576D61031.description:
locating, identifying, and describing the impact of Virginia’s bodies of water on its history,
economy, and culture.

4FC5E9720B1C4523B8C4991D17125139.description:
locating and describing the relative location and physical characteristics of Virginia's five
geographic regions on a map; and

B3909AE53E1E4750843F8614ADBA1FBB.description: locating Virginia and its bordering states on maps of the United States and North America;

F06C919CD2D748AB9C17D9AB0AEFE958.description:
The student will apply history and social science skills to explain the relationship between
physical geography and the lives of Virginia’s peoples, past and present by

B812B6111E9B4EE6A00CA06A8A15470E.description: developing products that reflect an understanding of content.

D9472A43732A48A88CC5AC8051AE5ECD.description:
practicing civility, respect, hard work, honesty, trustworthiness, and responsible citizenship
skills; and

2CBA770E407E4FE4B6A1EB97E3BACBBC.description:
using economic decision-making models to make informed economic decisions and to
explain the incentives and consequences of a specific choice;

8FED009BC5274EBBA3E091D664F9D707.description: identifying cause-and-effect relationships to clarify and explain content;

AA8435B6EA894931AD387BA1A5EEE4BD.description: comparing and contrasting people, places, and events;

1EF9231F35D349189FA0714D0F4DD49D.description: using evidence to construct timelines, classify events, and distinguish fact from opinion;

94C75AECDB2844D9BF03A12DE7D841A8.description: developing questions, enhancing curiosity, and engaging in critical thinking and analysis;

EEB751A568A741059ED46F7E9D026E8D.description: applying geographic skills to identify and understand geographic features and connections;

76ABA3801FE74D57921ABA648B51B996.description:
analyzing and interpreting information sources, including but not limited to artifacts,
primary and secondary sources, charts, graphs, and diagrams;

191166F616974A2C97176AB72CFD1A01.description: The student will apply history and social science skills to the content by
